Federal Court
Pinard, J.
May 5, 2011.
Counsel:
Sawsan A. Habbal, for the applicant;
Banafsheh Sokhansanj, for the respondents.
Solicitors of Record:
Sawsan A. Habbal, Vancouver, British Columbia, for the applicant;
Myles J. Kirvan, Deputy Attorney General of Canada, Vancouver, British Columbia, for the respondents.
Summary:
This case is unedited, therefore contains no summary. Any footnotes found in this case will appear below end of document.

[1]
Pinard, J.
: This is a motion on behalf of the applicant for a stay of execution of a valid deportation order against him pending disposition of his application for leave and for judicial review of his third Pre-Removal Risk Assessment ("PRRA"), dated March 29, 2011. The deportation is scheduled for May 5, 2011, in the evening.

[2]
The arguments of the applicant with respect to whether there is a serious issue in this matter deal basically with the reasonableness of the impugned decision. At this stage, I have serious doubts as to the existence of any valid reason to substitute my own appreciation of the facts to that made by the PRRA officer. In any event, without deciding whether there is a serious question to be determined by the Court, the requested stay is denied on the grounds that the applicant has failed to establish that he will suffer irreparable harm if he is removed to Lebanon, and to show that the balance of convenience is in his favour (see
 <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED> ).

[3]
With respect to the question of irreparable harm, the applicant's submission that his outstanding second Humanitarian and Compassionate ("H&C") application, filed just two weeks ago and based primarily on his establishment in Canada, will be rendered moot should he be removed from Canada, is without merit. It is trite law that neither an H&C application nor a judicial review application is rendered moot by the mere fact that a person has been deported (see
 <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED> ).

[4]
In fact, the applicant has had a previous H&C application which examined his establishment in Canada and which was refused. He has also had the benefit of a spousal sponsorship application with his then spouse which also was refused, in that case for lack of
bona fides
.

[5]
Concerning the allegation of harm to the applicant's companion and her children, as well as the contractors paid by the applicant, the Supreme Court of Canada  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  MacDonald Inc
, supra, at para 58, has held that harm to a third party, as opposed to the applicant, does not meet the "irreparable" threshold for the purposes of a stay motion (see also
 <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED> ).

[6]
Furthermore, irreparable harm must be something more than the inherent consequences of deportation.  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  at para 21, Mr. Justice Denis Pelletier stated:
. . . if the phrase "irreparable harm" is to retain any meaning at all, it must refer to some prejudice beyond that which is inherent in the notion of deportation itself. To be deported is to lose your job, to be separated from familiar faces and places. It is accompanied by enforced separation and heartbreak. . . .

[7]
The applicant's argument that the loss of his business will cause irreparable harm is also without merit. As held by this Court in
 <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  Canada does not equate to irreparable harm.

[8]
Finally, there is no new evidence before me to demonstrate that the applicant, who has benefitted from an assessment of his refugee claim, three risk assessments and reviews by this Court, faces a risk to his life if he is removed. In the circumstances, the balance of convenience lies with the respondent, as section 48 of the
Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
, SC 2001, c 27, provides that an enforceable removal order must be enforced as soon as is reasonably practicable.
ORDER

[9]
For the above mentioned reasons, the applicant's motion for an order staying the execution of the deportation order against him is dismissed.
[End of document]

statutes: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act , SC 2001, c 27, section 48
legal_issues: The standard for demonstrating irreparable harm in the context of a stay of deportation.
Whether harm to third parties can constitute irreparable harm sufficient to warrant a stay of deportation.
The impact of a deportation order on pending applications for humanitarian and compassionate grounds or judicial review.
The assessment of reasonableness of a pre-removal risk assessment.
The balance of convenience in deciding a motion for a stay of deportation, considering statutory obligations to enforce removal orders.
factual_background: An individual (the applicant) sought a stay of execution of a deportation order.
The deportation was scheduled to occur on May 5, 2011.
The applicant had previously submitted a Humanitarian and Compassionate (H&C) application that was refused.
A spousal sponsorship application for the applicant was also previously refused due to concerns about its legitimacy.
The applicant filed a new H&C application two weeks prior to the scheduled deportation, based on their establishment in Canada.
The applicant argued that deportation would cause harm to a companion, their children, and contractors.
The applicant claimed the loss of their business would constitute irreparable harm.
The applicant had undergone a refugee claim assessment, and three risk assessments and reviews by the court.
The applicant's motion for a stay was based on a challenge to a Pre-Removal Risk Assessment (PRRA) dated March 29, 2011.

Applicants: Deportation would render the applicant’s outstanding Humanitarian and Compassionate (H&C) application moot.
Deportation would cause harm to the applicant’s companion and her children.
Deportation would cause harm to contractors paid by the applicant.
Loss of the applicant’s business constitutes irreparable harm.
The applicant faces a risk to his life if removed to Lebanon.
Respondents: An H&C application or judicial review application is not rendered moot by deportation.
Harm to third parties does not meet the “irreparable” threshold for a stay motion.
Irreparable harm must be more than the inherent consequences of deportation.
Loss of a business does not equate to irreparable harm.
The applicant has already benefitted from multiple assessments and reviews, and there is no new evidence of risk to his life upon removal.

court_analysis: The court denied the applicant's motion for a stay of deportation, finding the applicant failed to demonstrate irreparable harm or that the balance of convenience favoured him.

The court dismissed the argument that the applicant’s pending Humanitarian and Compassionate (H&C) application would be mooted by deportation, citing established legal precedent that deportation does not automatically render such applications moot.

The court found that harm to third parties (the applicant’s companion and her children, and his contractors) does not meet the threshold for ‘irreparable harm’ required for a stay, relying on Supreme Court of Canada jurisprudence.

The court clarified that ‘irreparable harm’ must be more than the inherent consequences of deportation itself – such as job loss and separation from family and community – and referenced prior case law defining this standard.
The court rejected the argument that the loss of the applicant’s business constituted irreparable harm, citing a previous decision of the same court.
The court determined there was no new evidence presented to suggest the applicant faced a risk to his life upon removal to Lebanon, noting he had already undergone multiple assessments of his claims.

The court emphasized the statutory obligation under section 48 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act to enforce removal orders ‘as soon as is reasonably practicable’, finding this supported the balance of convenience favouring the respondent.
final_outcome: The applicant's motion for an order staying the execution of the deportation order against him is dismissed.
